segment.source: This is Iaan's test md page using VS2015.
segment.target: This is Iaan's test md page using VS2015.

segment.source: So what did I do?
segment.target: So what did I do?

segment.source: Here's some answers yo:
segment.target: Here's some answers yo:

segment.source: So you can check-in/check-out and manage files in the GitHub repos:
segment.target: So you can check-in/check-out and manage files in the GitHub repos:

segment.source: Install VS2015 and choose the 'custom' option.
segment.target: Install VS2015 and choose the 'custom' option.

segment.source: On the next screen, at the bottom, you need to select the two Git-related options.
segment.target: On the next screen, at the bottom, you need to select the two Git-related options.

segment.source: So you can see a preview of your .md files in VS2015:
segment.target: So you can see a preview of your .md files in VS2015:

segment.source: Install VS Web EssentialsLink to download the latest Web Essentials version - you can also search for it in the extensions manager in VS.
segment.target: Install VS Web EssentialsLink to download the latest Web Essentials version - you can also search for it in the extensions manager in VS.

segment.source: To understand more about how to use GitHub and VS2015, check these out:
segment.target: To understand more about how to use GitHub and VS2015, check these out:

segment.source: WDG-CPUB test instructions
segment.target: WDG-CPUB test instructions

segment.source: The WDG repo on github.com
segment.target: The WDG repo on github.com

segment.source: Preview (and live) version of the WDG repo on MSDN
segment.target: Preview (and live) version of the WDG repo on MSDN

segment.source: Channel 9 guide to connecting GitHub repos to VS2015
segment.target: Channel 9 guide to connecting GitHub repos to VS2015

segment.source: Tutorial on creating a GitHub project
segment.target: Tutorial on creating a GitHub project

segment.source: Here's what we're going to do in our little excursion
segment.target: Here's what we're going to do in our little excursion

segment.source: 1.1 Make changes and review them all on github.com
segment.target: 1.1 Make changes and review them all on github.com

segment.source: Go to the wdg-cpub-test repo on github.com and navigate to the readme.md file
segment.target: Go to the wdg-cpub-test repo on github.com and navigate to the readme.md file

segment.source: Make an update on the site to include this URL for msdnstage:
segment.target: Make an update on the site to include this URL for msdnstage:

segment.source: https://msdnstage.redmond.corp.microsoft.com/wdg-cpub-test/HelloWorld
segment.target: https://msdnstage.redmond.corp.microsoft.com/wdg-cpub-test/HelloWorld

segment.source: Request a pull change
segment.target: Request a pull change

segment.source: 1.2a Use VS2015 to pull files from a repo
segment.target: 1.2a Use VS2015 to pull files from a repo

segment.source: Click the Manage Connections icon at the top of the Team Explorer window.
segment.target: Click the Manage Connections icon at the top of the Team Explorer window.

segment.source: You should see a GitHub section (if this doesn't appear, you may need to sign in first).
segment.target: You should see a GitHub section (if this doesn't appear, you may need to sign in first).

segment.source: Click Clone and search for a project (eg wdg-cpub) from the list.
segment.target: Click Clone and search for a project (eg wdg-cpub) from the list.

segment.source: Make sure it's going in your dedicated GitHub syncs folder.
segment.target: Make sure it's going in your dedicated GitHub syncs folder.

segment.source: Click Clone.
segment.target: Click Clone.

segment.source: This will pull all the files in the repo onto your local machine.
segment.target: This will pull all the files in the repo onto your local machine.

segment.source: Use File Explorer to go to the location of the repo and you can see the files.
segment.target: Use File Explorer to go to the location of the repo and you can see the files.

segment.source: You can copy the files to somewhere else on your machine to open them and play around with them without fear that you will make changes on the server.
segment.target: You can copy the files to somewhere else on your machine to open them and play around with them without fear that you will make changes on the server.

segment.source: 1.2b Use VS2015 to push files to a repo
segment.target: 1.2b Use VS2015 to push files to a repo

segment.source: To make changes appear on the server, open up the file from within your local folder and make the changes.
segment.target: To make changes appear on the server, open up the file from within your local folder and make the changes.

segment.source: Save the file and go back to VS2015.
segment.target: Save the file and go back to VS2015.

segment.source: Generally, you should make branches when you are making changes.
segment.target: Generally, you should make branches when you are making changes.

segment.source: See Team Workflow for more information.
segment.target: See Team Workflow for more information.

segment.source: Click the Manage Connections icon at the top of the Team Explorer window.
segment.target: Click the Manage Connections icon at the top of the Team Explorer window.

segment.source: You should see a GitHub section (if this doesn't appear, you may need to sign in first).
segment.target: You should see a GitHub section (if this doesn't appear, you may need to sign in first).

segment.source: Double-click the repo you want to update in the list of Local Git Respositories.
segment.target: Double-click the repo you want to update in the list of Local Git Respositories.

segment.source: This will open the repo and take you to Team Explorer.
segment.target: This will open the repo and take you to Team Explorer.

segment.source: Click Branches.
segment.target: Click Branches.

segment.source: right click on master and click New local branch from....
segment.target: right click on master and click New local branch from....

segment.source: Enter a name for the new branch (describing what you did or the date maybe).
segment.target: Enter a name for the new branch (describing what you did or the date maybe).

segment.source: Click Create Branch.
segment.target: Click Create Branch.

segment.source: Go to Changes.
segment.target: Go to Changes.

segment.source: You'll see the files you updated, and the new branch should be selected by default.
segment.target: You'll see the files you updated, and the new branch should be selected by default.

segment.source: If not, click on the branch name, which will take you to Branches.
segment.target: If not, click on the branch name, which will take you to Branches.

segment.source: Double-click the new branch, then go back to Changes.
segment.target: Double-click the new branch, then go back to Changes.

segment.source: Enter a description and click Commit.
segment.target: Enter a description and click Commit.

segment.source: Go to Sync.
segment.target: Go to Sync.

segment.source: You'll see the an open publish request.
segment.target: You'll see the an open publish request.

segment.source: Click Publish.
segment.target: Click Publish.

segment.source: Your local changes are now on the github.com server.
segment.target: Your local changes are now on the github.com server.

segment.source: You can go there to see them.
segment.target: You can go there to see them.

segment.source: 1.3 Use VS2015 to do it all (connect to a github repo, make changes, sync with github.com)
segment.target: 1.3 Use VS2015 to do it all (connect to a github repo, make changes, sync with github.com)

segment.source: Click the Manage Connections icon at the top of the Team Explorer window.
segment.target: Click the Manage Connections icon at the top of the Team Explorer window.

segment.source: You should see a GitHub section (if this doesn't appear, you may need to sign in first).
segment.target: You should see a GitHub section (if this doesn't appear, you may need to sign in first).

segment.source: You have two options, which depend on whether you've created a repo on github.com already and want to use it, or if you want to create a new repo right now:
segment.target: You have two options, which depend on whether you've created a repo on github.com already and want to use it, or if you want to create a new repo right now:

segment.source: Under GitHub, click Create.
segment.target: Under GitHub, click Create.

segment.source: Enter the name, a description, the local sync path you want to use (it's a good idea to keep all your syncs in one folder, on a non-OS partition).
segment.target: Enter the name, a description, the local sync path you want to use (it's a good idea to keep all your syncs in one folder, on a non-OS partition).

segment.source: Click Create.
segment.target: Click Create.

segment.source: In this example we'll use Testing for the name, and F:\Gits for the path.
segment.target: In this example we'll use Testing for the name, and F:\Gits for the path.

segment.source: If you have an existing repo, click Clone and select it from the list. Click Clone*.
segment.target: If you have an existing repo, click Clone and select it from the list. Click Clone*.

segment.source: Your repo will appear in the list of Local Git Respositories.
segment.target: Your repo will appear in the list of Local Git Respositories.

segment.source: Double-click it to open the repo in Team Explorer.
segment.target: Double-click it to open the repo in Team Explorer.

segment.source: Under Solutions click New....
segment.target: Under Solutions click New....

segment.source: Under Templates\Other Project Types\Visual Studio Solutions select Blank Solution, give it the same name as the repo you just created: Testing.
segment.target: Under Templates\Other Project Types\Visual Studio Solutions select Blank Solution, give it the same name as the repo you just created: Testing.

segment.source: Change the Location to be the parent folder of the repo you just created: F:\Gits.
segment.target: Change the Location to be the parent folder of the repo you just created: F:\Gits.

segment.source: Select Add to source control and click OK.
segment.target: Select Add to source control and click OK.

segment.source: Go to Changes, enter a description and click Commit.
segment.target: Go to Changes, enter a description and click Commit.

segment.source: Go to Sync.
segment.target: Go to Sync.

segment.source: You'll see an open push request.
segment.target: You'll see an open push request.

segment.source: Click Push.
segment.target: Click Push.

segment.source: You've now created a repo on github.com, and synced it with your local copy.
segment.target: You've now created a repo on github.com, and synced it with your local copy.

segment.source: It only contains a readme.md, but if you go to github.com, you'll see the repo has been created.
segment.target: It only contains a readme.md, but if you go to github.com, you'll see the repo has been created.

segment.source: Now you can start working on files.
segment.target: Now you can start working on files.

segment.source: Go to the Solution Explorer in VS2015.
segment.target: Go to the Solution Explorer in VS2015.

segment.source: Here you'll see the files you have.
segment.target: Here you'll see the files you have.

segment.source: Right-click to add a new file, choose a text document, and call it whatever you want.
segment.target: Right-click to add a new file, choose a text document, and call it whatever you want.

segment.source: Make sure it has .md as the extension (this ensures it is a MarkDown document).
segment.target: Make sure it has .md as the extension (this ensures it is a MarkDown document).

segment.source: You can now edit it in VS2015.
segment.target: You can now edit it in VS2015.

segment.source: To push your changes, go to Team Explorer, then follow Steps 8 and 9 in Section 1.3 above.
segment.target: To push your changes, go to Team Explorer, then follow Steps 8 and 9 in Section 1.3 above.
